Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: AC-Supercapacitors for Power Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is an innovative new capacitor technology based on kilohertz high-frequency supercapacitor, called AC-Supercap, aiming to replace conventional aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) for a vast range of electronic and power systems. Capacitors are an essential component used in electronic devices, in power supplies driving electrical machines, appliances and instruments, as well as in power conversion and conditioning systems used for renewable energy generation. In the consumer electronics sector, miniaturization and low-profile or even flexible packaging, and higher power efficiency are some of the key demands. In the power system and other power-demanding industry sectors, large capacitance, large ripple current absorption, and high temperature rating are the key requirements. With the emergence of distributed wireless sensors and Internet of Things (IoT), pulse energy storage and generation will be necessary as well. AC-Supercap, with its much better performance than current solutions, is anticipated to better serve the needs of broad range of customers. Upon the success of this technology, there will also be tremendous impact on the local ecosystem and regional community of West Texas.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will investigate the feasibility of producing AC-Supercap as high-performance alternating current (AC) filtering capacitors for power modules, on-board application, or as compact and efficient pulse power storage. Conventional AECs, limited by their low capacitance density, bulky size, poor lifetime, large equivalent series resistance, and polarity sensitivity cannot meet technical needs well. To achieve AC-Supercaps with both large capacitance density and high-frequency response, two contradictory requirements, and nanostructured electrode engineering will be investigated. To produce a compact capacitor with a large voltage rating and capacitance, multicell integration will be optimally designed and demonstrated, which is crucial considering the intrinsic low voltage rating of a single cell. The proposed innovative solutions to these technical challenges will de-risk the AC-Supercap product prototyping in the following project phases to make ready the technology for commercialization. These research activities will advance the scientific understanding and technological development of nanostructured electrode process and property control, multicell integration design, and particularly AC-Supercap technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With billions of pieces sold every year, aluminum electrolytic capacitor (AEC) is a ubiquitous component used in any power related circuit design for current ripple filtering in power conversion and power conditioning for electronic devices, as well as for industrial power supplies, solar and wind based renewable energy generation and many others. They may also be used as fast energy storage for environmental pulse energy harvesting or as pulse power generators for strobe applications. Unlike integrated circuit (IC) technology, with dramatically increased integration density resulting in smaller and smaller IC chips over the years, AEC technology has undergone no obvious evolution in decades, and the large size of AEC has become the limiting factor in downscaling the printed circuit board and hence the dimensions of electronic systems. Conventional supercapacitors have a capacitance density several orders of magnitude greater than electrolytic capacitors, but only work efficiently at frequencies below ~ 1 Hz, and therefore they should be called as DC-supercapacitors. They cannot duplicate the functions of AECs that work at hundreds to kilo-hertz frequencies. The resistance caused power loss is another issue of AEC. 

BaoNano, LLC, partnering with Texas Tech University, are developing and commercializing nanostructured electrodes for supercapacitors capable of running at kilo-hertz frequencies, or AC-SupercapsTM, which can replace AECs with a volume size reduction of more than 10 times, and the resistance loss will also be significantly reduced. In particular, we use carbon nanofibers and microfibers, in conjunction with oriented graphene flakes to design the nanostructured electrodes which can simultaneously provide large capacitance density and high-frequency response. 

With the Phase I STTR grant from the National Science Foundation, we successfully demonstrated the proof-of-concept of AC-Supercap that met the functions and performance proposed in Phase I proposal.  The breakthroughs we have achieved in the Phase I project include: establishing the process to produce carbon nanofiber thin films; establishing the process to produce interconnected carbon nanofibers with improved conductivity and reduced interfacial resistance between the current collector and the carbon nanofiber film; modifying carbon nanofiber surface to simultaneously achieve kilohertz high-frequency response and large electrode capacitance (> 2 mF/cm2); develop a new carbon nanofiber electrode manufacture process with reduced cost;  proof-concept demonstration of multiple cells interconnection to increase rated voltage and capacitance; proof-concept demonstration of encapsulation and packaging,  functionally demonstrate AC-Supercap for current ripple filtering in AC/DC converter.

The results of the research conducted in this NSF STTR Phase I project demonstrate the commercial feasibility of our AC-Supercap technology, which can be used for ripple current filtering, pulse generation and many other applications in electronics and power systems, with a compact size and much better performance than the existing capacitor solutions. These proof-of-concept results and demonstration lay the foundation for the expansion of R&D to create prototyping devices in Phase II and the subsequent beta testing for commercialization. Our customer discovery and market research indicate that our AC-Supercap will be an attractive capacitor technology with a huge market.

 


Last Modified: 09/17/2019
Modified by: Nazifah Islam
